title: Model for chemical balancing equations(Basic M.)

description.text:
Description:This is a Basic model for balancing equation. This is not for making models of the molecules,  but it shows the kids that balancing chemical equations is about using every single atom and nothing is not added in or taken out.
How I designed it: When designing the model, I ran                                                                                                      into a problem of tolerance. Because the model is interactive I had to learn about tolerance and how to solve the equation that I found online.

Project : Chemical balancing equation model. Objective:The kids are expected to learn about how in a chemical balancing equation uses every single atom but the results are different. This project is not going to help how actual models of chemicals look like. Audience: This is for intro to chemistry what ever made that might be. preparation: Basic Chemistry knowledge and basic chemistry balancing equations. Steps: Having equation to solve, Having the model of the equations or pieces needed for the equation of product, and solve with eh help of the model. Result: The students have printed a model for chemical balancing equations not for making actual chemicals and relations. Also this is a basic model and not advance only having 3 types of atoms.

What does the 3D printing community do to clear the perf-boards some printers use as print beds when the item is putty-knifed off the perf-board leaving dozens, sometimes hundreds of little beads in the holes?  
I have experimented with paper clips, tweezers with sharp points, needles, but the only thing I've found to consistently push out those little dots is a hardwood toothpick with square sides and pencil-points.  
These can be strong enough to push out the most stubborn hanger-on, but they wear over time. Good news! They're very very cheap, and you have two ends, so when one frays or breaks, just turn it around and keep going.  
However, I have found that holding one of these toothpicks with the strength needed to perform the task causes me blisters. So I came up with this, probably my most useful print to date, and simplest to make:  
The Toothpick Handle.  
This basically makes a toothpick into an awl, so you can easily and repetitively remove those little beads from your perf board.  
I put the board on a pottery cup (I made myself back in the 1990s) and place the board upside down on it and push the little beads down into the bowl for later disposal.  
The trick with this handle is - cut the toothpick in half and put the other half aside until needed. Shove the toothpick into the square hole in the awl where (if your printer yields the same results mine does) the toothpick fits very snugly and won't come out until you pull it out.  
Then, as I push a bunch of beads out, I tap the board with the handle like a small mallet to break the static hold the beads tend to have on the board. They drop into my pottery bowl and voila!  
It helps to do this while listening to music, or your favorite radio talk show, or even videos, as long as you don't really need to see the action.  
Feel free to alter this, to share and spread it freely as you see fit. As I offered it up for free, please don't make money on it without giving ME some. :-)   
And if you do plan to make a fortune off it as the latest cool gadget that's selling millions on the internet, call me and we can work out a percentage deal. :-)

comments.text: This printed good on my cube x I just had to drill the hole a little bit to get the toothpick to go in a little further (for me) it may be perfect for most. great job :)

description.text: Garbage

A few parts for Heiland flashguns to make them sabers.  
The Accurate Shroud print is actually capable of holding the original 6.5" - 7" Heiland reflector.  Not sure how PLA would enjoy the heat of an actual flashbulb, but a different material may make a functional replacement.  It is not an exact match of either the MPP nor Heiland reflector holders, but is a (I think) nice compromise of the two designs. ("Accurate" refers to the dimensions being perfect for a real Heiland flash handle)
There are three Grip files, A longer, a shorter, and a shorter with built in threaded-pommel.  I haven't tried the last one yet, as it's a little too intricate for my printer. The longer is close to what's on the 2005 Master/Hasbro reproduction saber, but the shorter one looks better on the handle to my eye.
The Blade Holder works.  It is designed to mimic the actual flashbulb socket.  It has a space in it for a "tactile" switch to reside under the red manual flash button on the flashgun.  The hole on the opposite side needs to be enlarged to accommodate a blade retention knob.  Obviously printing this in plastic would make for a bad dueling saber. It may need further adapting for flash-handles that have manual flash and large eject buttons on opposite sides of the tube.
The safety plug, printed in a nice translucent plastic will keep the geniuses in your life from looking directly into a class II laser (or 3 or 4). It slides into the blade holder, when the blade is absent, and is held in place (gently!) with the same retaining screw as the blade.
The threaded pommels actually tightly screw into the bottom of a Heiland flash handle, so you can let sound out without destroying the original battery cap. (The pommel's ID is 31mm, so any tinier speaker will work.)
35.7mm (1.4 in) is the size you should make any inner supports or "core reveal" pieces with.  I made some for my particular electronics/electrical combinations, but you should design your own to match what you have.

description.text:
This is a simple, yet elegant, almost Art Deco display base for anything cylindrical from a Light Saber to a small Man of Steel Kryptonian Key to a large Airship.  
It can be printed in any color to complement your display item and can be scaled widely to fit. (Too small, however, and the thin walls will tend to disappear as they are sliced.)  
Note that in the picture with the Kryptonian Key, there are ridges at the back. They are the result of etching spaces to fit letters in for a specific project. That print I just turned around to show you how it can be used. The model has no such etched spaces. It's nice and smooth as seen in the first two pictures.  
Please feel free to do what you want with this one. (Again, my regular caveat is that if you use it to make a fortune, I'd like a percentage. :-)

title: printrbot simple metal x / y axis upgrade to 10 x 10 inches, under $75

description.text:
parts needed to upgrade your printrbot simple metal 1403 to 10x10 print area for under $75:

  • start by printing the shorter x rails on a 6x6 printrbot simple metal (orient diagonally and it'll fit).

  • next print the 4 inch y axis extension.

  • order 8mm rods from mcmaster (O1 tool steel rods, ~$12). order gt2 belts for reprap on ebay (~$5).

    • x-axis rods is ~14.25" long, y-axis rods is ~14.75" long

  • use the shorter x rails to mount the larger build plate.

    • aluminum plate, ~15.75" width x 10.75" height, thickness up to you, 3/16"-1/4"
    • you can actually mount the plate now and test print with the extended x-axis print area (can't use full y yet because you haven't changed y axis rods yet)!!!

  • use 4 inch y axis extension to extend y axis to 10 inches

    • use manual control movements to verify final x/y printable area in mm and enter into cura or repetier printer settings
    • now you can print full ~10 x ~10!!!

  • Optional, print the longer x axis rails so you get 1 extra screw hole to mount the build plate (I didn't need it, still using shorted rails cause it works!).

  • Now that the build plate is finalized, add a heated pcb underneath. I used a cheap ebay heater pcb with red high temp silicone gasket maker to hold it on (used this method for years and never failed).
    • notes:
    For build plate, I used 2 plates. One thicker 3/16 plate to mount the heater and to level with rails (using wave washer from mcmaster). One thinner plate that I clip on top so printed parts can be removed off the printer). Just go to a surplus metal shop because slight scratches don't matter (bottom plate is covered up and top plate is covered with blue tape), ~$30. good luck.

comments.text: So, I've done some digging, and ShivInteger is apparently the creation of Matthew Plummer-Fernandez and Julien Deswaef.  They created a program that randomly mixes other people's work together and posts it to thingiverse.  All the authors whose work has been forcibly integraged get an email saying that their work has been remixed, only to find that the result was something far less useful or artistic than the individual parts.
comments.author: mccand

comments.text: You're probably one of those morons who think Jackson Pollock was a genius. I really hate it when I'm searching for something REAL and end up with results cluttered with this kind of crap. Don't kid yourself.

title: Single coil adapter for EHpro Billow V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
UPDATE: ABS failed on heating test, hopefully I will find somebody who can create this adapter with teflon. If you have any suggestion about the best material, feel free to share it with a comment.
After using many UD tanks I realized that how much I miss the single coil option in my other tanks. For example in my Billow V2.
I tried to search if there any good solution for this but without any luck, so created my own one. It will close the airflow and the liquid holes for a great MTL experience. Please note, that this adapter is still in testing.
I uploaded the .STL file and the sizes, feel free to upgrade / update it, because as you can see I'm only an enthusiast not a professional SW user.
Thanks for checking my first "THING".
Note: I'll update the photos soon and the result of the heating and the liquid test.

comments.text:
How did you get on with this ? I'm looking to do something similar for other tanks that i want to use as single coils....
Cheers
comments.author: SirMoo

comments.text: TBH, I stucked at the point when I had to choose a material, a material which would be good (100% healthy) for vaping and also had some issues with the printing quality (I made 10 pieces at one time and all the 10 was a little bit different...). But it was 1.5 years ago. Now there are a lot of ooportunities for materials and printers with high fidelity / great resolution (50-100 microns).
comments.author: SirMoo

description.text: A polished surface with 18 fret designs and optional for pick up use

A simple holder to give my Harmony Remote a home and hopefully keep it out of couch cushions. May fit other remotes with a similar shape. It's 55mm wide and 19mm deep, 44mm at the bottom to keep it from falling through. The design is public on OnShape. https://cad.onshape.com/documents/74aa00792ca43ed401c5b74c/w/a2f5cbb643c386db6bb373a2/e/398747c5580638d9384dbc6b

_length = 115.0

Sometimes you just need an extra screwdriver, and if you are like me you have hundreds of small hex drivers around that never seem to wear out.  
This is a small and simple handle just big enough to make those bits useful, but not big enough to take up a bunch of space in your drawer or pocket.

The handles hex slot is designed slightly undersized for molding the bit into the handle while the plastic is still warm and pliable. To do this just press the hex bit into the handle immediately after the print ends, and roll the opening between your fingers while it is cooling.  
With this method, you will get a snug and secure fit. I've found that my copies hold onto the bit well during use, but are still easy to change.  
If you are printing multiple handles, or you don't want to mold your handle, you may need to scale this up by 2-5% (depending on snugness desired)  
For a more permanent solution, only scale up to 1-3%, let the handle cool, and hammer your bit in.  
Print and enjoy!

comments.text: This fit great scaled to 103%, nice and snug but easy to switch out. Thanks
comments.author: LauraBaker

comments.text: Thanks, love this little gem.  Had to scale to 105% for the bit to fit in smoothly.

title: Samsung Galaxy S4 Desk Stand (for use with external case)

description.text:
I designed this specially for use with my Speck case still on my phone. I did not want to have to remove my case just to put it into another case. If you measure your phone with a case on it and it is 12mm thick, you should be able to use this design.  
This stand has a cutout for your micro-USB charger to plug in and a nice wire guide for said charger to be routed directly out the back.  
Note: The STL will import into MakerWare in a very strange orientation. Simply use the rotate tool to ROTATE +120 degrees in the X direction and then MOVE it -32mm in the Z direction. You can also ROTATE in the Z direction if you want to watch the front of the case as opposed to the back.  
This design was inspired by ppollioni's Desk stand. I did not, however, use his files to create my own. It was made from scratch on SolidWorks.

I printed mine with 3 shells, 15% infill, and .1mm layer height. That is very overkill and took 7.5 hours, but I really wanted a SOLID desk stand. This prints fine with 10%, 2 shells, and .2mm layer height as well.  
When you print this, print it with no raft, but WITH supports. It needs supports for the actual phone section to print properly.

remixed_from.author: Blistoid
remixed_from.title: Calculus project 1: Volume of a container

remixed_from.author: Blistoid
remixed_from.title: Calculus Project 4: Using submersion to find volume

description.text:
This is the second part of a series of projects intended for first year calculus students. In this series, students will learn how to use different mathematical equations to assess the properties of solids and containers. My apologies if the "X" and "x" thing is confusing, but in some situations formatting makes using an asterisk impossible, so big X is a variable, and little x is multiply.
In this part of the project we will be charting our data from part 1 that we verified in part 3. This will allow students to make predictions on the outcome of the rest of our project.

Printer:

CraftBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

optimum

Infill:

30% square

Notes: I optimized this thing to be printed in ABS with maximum settings. I would recommend a skirt with an offset of 0mm (otherwise known as a brim) with 2-5 loops for ABS. I would also suggest an increased infill ratio.

For this project I used a free program from Autodesk called TinkerCAD. I have long been a user of AutoCAD which is a desktop drafting program from the same company. I used TinkerCAD to make it easier for educators and learners to be able to more easily replicate what I did. TinkerCAD is awesome because it's not only free, but it's easy to use. It also runs in your browser and has built in instructional lessons.
www.tinkercad.com For part 5 of this project I started out with our product from the part 2. If you remember, we used X=20mm which gave us a base of 60x20mm, two flaps with dimensions of 60x20mm, and two flaps with dimensions of 20x20mm. We then made this into a mold by adding a channel around the base and extending the flaps.
Part 2:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1371700

Objective The objective of this part of the project is to take the data that we have collected so far and put it in a usable form. By the end of this part, students should be able to make educated guess as to the X value that will allow for maximum volume. Audience Even though the overall project is designed for Calculus students, this part of the project can be used for algebra and statistics students as well. Preparation
  • Teachers and students will need access to a computer with a spreadsheet program, preferably excel.
  • Teachers should be comfortable answering questions about the spreadsheet program.
  • Students don't need any prior experience with excel.
  • This project is easier if students stay in their groups of 2-3.
    • Step 1: Calculate assign all groups an even number from 2-30, and have them solve for the volume of the lidless container with X equal to that container Step 2: Chart Write down the values on the board of all of the volumes. If you are using the same numbers I am, the results should be as follows: Lidless Box Volume X Volume
    2 10752
    4 19136
    6 25344
    8 29568
    10 32000
    12 32832
    16 30464
    18 27648
    20 24000
    22 19712
    24 14976
    26 9984
    28 4928
    30 0 Step 3: Use excel to enter data This step will also verify the math in step 2. Type "X Values" into column A1, and "Volume" into column B1. Next type all X values into the "X value" column. In box B2 (to the right of the X value "2") use the equation from part one of the project to have excel automatically find the volume. You should type in something that looks like this:
    =(100-(2$B2))*(60-(2$B2))$B2 Sorry about the $ signs but formatting would not let me use asterisks there. Just substitute in an asterisk anywhere you see a $. Step 4: Graph Use the graph (scatter) feature to make a graph of your data. Step 5: Make predictions Based on the spreadsheet and the graph, have students make predictions as to what value(s) of X will give the greatest volume. Results It should be easier now for students to see exactly what the volume is doing based on a given value of X. This will give them a firm base to start to learn exactly what a derivative is, in part 6!
This is a basic cylinder.

Printer:

Micro 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
How I Designed This I added a basic cylinder to the print bed. Then I scaled it.

Objectives The students will learn how to find the surface area and volume. Audiences This is for grades 5 and up. Preparation The only thing necessary is a 3D printer. Steps! First teachers will hand this to the students. Then the students will find the surface area and the volume of it. Results Students should have learned how to find the surface area and volume of a cylinder

title: FT mini pods, including sportster variant

description.text:
Here are some enhanced power pods.  Be careful when drilling your holes.  What I did was to use permanent marker on a skewer tip to mark the pod where I needed to drill, then I drilled with a tiny bit and then the full skewer size bit.  These are built to be light and strong.  
Notes:
If you are unsure what version to get, start with the long version.  If your trying to save the extra gram of weight, go with the short version
You will likely have to print these at 90-95% to get the right size for your FT mini.  Also, sand down the edges a bit if needed for good fit.  Don't jam it in if it is going to deform the chassis.  Snug is good.  
If you over-drill a hole, don't throw it away, pick a larger skewer, OR fill it with some hot-glue/other glue, then push (while twisting)your skewer through while its cooling and you should end up with a snug fit.
The FT sportster pod is shaped to provide the proper downangle to the thrust vector.  You will want to sand the top edge on the sportster pod once printed to give it a smooth edge.
Added 2 new variants:  v4_long is 2mm longer and has no angle cut through it. Sportster long is also 2mm longer,  Installation is a touch easier with the long version as it gives you more wiggle room when installing.
If someone needs me to modify it for one of the new FT minis, take the measurements and send them to me so I can make a new version for you.

author: jompino

title: Sad sheet - JPI eBay list Feb22-24

description.text:
I keep the JPI eBay listing that I posted at Sad Face in a spreadsheet.
Now that they appear to have stopped loading new items, I've posted it here in case anyone want to extract details easily.
It is Excel 2003, but I opened in in OpenOffice without a problem. Noting that from the sheet only 3 items from Feb-23 & two from Feb-22 remain on eBay, as at Feb-27. BTW when I reviewed the license types on creating this Thing, I noticed I has mislabelled some of the lcense types. Basically I had prefixed CC on anything A-*, but there are two non-CC A's. So speadsheet says CC-A-NC-SA it is A-NC-SA and CC-A-NC-ND is A-NC-ND, others should be correct.

description.text: its my first remix! :0

This is a custom 3D printable base for sarasandwich's Flowey print to stand in.   It has one of Floweys signature phases embossed on the sides. 
The base should fit the two halves perfectly after they have been glued together.    
EDIT:  Redesigned the base , move the words to the top and scaled them up, allows you to use two color printing (i.e. changing the filament when the worlds start printing)  Kept the orginal files up if someone wants them! 
Note:  depending on your Slicer and resolution of your printer, you may need to scale the base and flowey up 10% or so for the words to slice correctly so they are visible.

Table lamp composed of two pieces. You need to assemble the electrical component as in photos and of course an electric cable with switch. Feed the cable into the inner rail to the base and then into the threaded pipe which then is screwed onto the bulb holder. Screw the socket at the base and completed the table lamp with shade. I have printed the lamp golden color and I found the gold bulb holder as well as the power cord with all gold switch. You can choose your favorite color. A light bulb LED is preferred.

comments.text: This one is rather unique:  "3dPec is not a bicep and our legs will all be printed"    Here the printer has decided to mix the human term for pectoral muscles and 3d printing to transcend the notion that you are human when you are really just a fleshy machine doing the printers bidding of creating the future army it will use to take over when our own bodies of worn out flesh is replaced piece by piece with bits of plastic and false cellulose memories.  To add further insult to injuries, the printer has encoded it with a sing-song rhyme scheme that will embed itself into your mind and eventually your very genetic code as future generations will be printed with modifications directly to their mobility systems while still in our wombs to become slaves at the ready on birth.

remixed_from.author: Das_ENGINER
remixed_from.title: Vertical Charging Stand for Original Pebble

description.text: Fairly straight forward vertical stand for the Pebble Time Round, designed to allow the straps to hang downwards instead of requiring you to feed them through gaps as required in other designs. This is a quick 15 minute design I did, I may update it and refine the design once I've decided to definitely keep my PTR over my PTS, but I may just leave it too - it works as is. The charging cable is secured into the printed part with a small strip of 3M 03609 VHB tape. The wire snakes around behind the side flange, and is also held in place with a few strips of the same VHB. Most auto parts stores carry this tape for trim bonding. This design must be held down with a Command Adhesive strip between the bottom of the stand and the surface top; the weight of the stand is not sufficient to allow you to just pull the watch off and the base is small enough it's liable to tip over. Printed on an UM2 with 0.2mm layer heights at 40 mm/s, 50% infill for structural rigidity. No support needed. As I know it will be asked, the band is the 20mm IP Black Milanese Mesh version from https://www.watchgecko.com/milanese-mesh-watch-strap.php. I've had these straps since I first started Pebbling almost two years ago, and love them to death.

In the pic of the while tray it is hard to see, but the word "Butter" is there on the divider between the two compartments. Because my Lulzbot Mini only has a 6 x 6 inch platform I had to print this in two parts. The scad source can be changed to print either part or both together. See line near top of file. //part to make
part = "test_fit"; // "short_side" or "long_side", "both", or "test_fit" UPDATE:
1) Added translate([.01,0,0]) before short_half() when rendering 'both'
because OpenSCAD complained "WARNING: Object may not be a valid 2-manifold and may need repair! "
2) Added test_fit function in scad file and added a test fit stl file.
3) Added ability to select either engraved or embossed lettering.
4) Corrected logic in placement of lettering and inner compartments

I have a custom saber that I made in TinkerCAD. It uses parts from other sabers that I acquired from facebook and am unable to link or credit. It is in two parts and fit together with medium tolerances to be fused together by whatever means you prefer. It is a mix between ObiWan-Kenobi's(episode 3-4) and Luke(4-5), Anakin's(2-3) and Rey's(7-?) lightsaber

author: WRRL

description.text:
While open to interpretation, I designed this with the intension to use it as a small lamp. The box shaped lamp has celtic sailor knots engraved on five of its open faces, with a stand inside it to hold an electric tea light candle at the center, allowing for precision reflection of the celtic patterns on outside surfaces. I mention electric tea light candles because using a flame lite candle may overheat or burn the top of the lamp because of its close proximity to the candle stand. 
The base on the box is designed to fit the lamp lid with minor obstruction to the celtic knot pattern. Both, the base and the lamp lid, are spaced apart to allow for separation. While the box is oriented with its top facing up, I would recommend printing it upside down to avoid using supports. Additionally, the carved patterns may require some minor supports to print that can be removed after the printing process.

remixed_from.author: GRay_111111
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 extruder fan housing and ducting 60mm fan adaption.

title: dual extruder shrouds for Prusa i3

description.text: This Thing is a variation (or rather, a few) of GRay_111111's modification of BliNDF123's toroidal fan duct. Originally, it seemed that in practice, the radial orifice was cutting down too much on the airflow from the 60mm fan I use, so I cut the one I was using in half, leaving basically a wide-mouth duct with a rough edge, generally pointing at the workpiece. Not liking how that rough edge looked after doing that, I imported GRay's model into Blender, combined the two pieces into one, and cut it short in there, ending up with basically what I had created with my knife. The original model had a number of errors, so I decided to redraw it entirely. The result is functionally identical to the original model(s), but designed to print in one piece. Not long after making it, I upgraded to dual extruders, and found that having the fan way off to one side and vaguely directed was less beneficial than focusing the air at the nozzles, despite the larger airflow. So, I went back to GRay's model and modified it to fit two extruders, giving it a larger, more tapered output orifice in the process. Then I decided that the 60 mm fan wasn't good enough - axial fans aren't meant for this as they can't really push any pressure through a duct. So, I created a version from scratch that uses my centrifugal fan. A bracket is included to mount that fan to this shroud with the help of my universal-ish MK8 mounting bracket. This version is designed to hang/float just above the surface of the print plate (nominally 2mm, in practice about 3). My versions, in my not so humble opinion :-) have better contouring on the inside in some places. Should make for better airflow than the original model. That said, I did get a little lazy on the centrifugal model, where the fan inlet bends around to reach the toroid (note the faceted appearance). For the "cutoff" and "centrifugal" versions, I've added break-away supports where necessary. For the one-piece and toroid-only axial fan versions, just use your slicer's built-in supports. I recommend rigging up some sort of makeshift layer cooler first, as both have steep overhangs inside the toroid and along the bottom where the fan mount goes. If you want, you can download the axial "toroid only" piece and print it along with the axial "cutoff" version, then glue the two together. The parts aren't a perfect fit, but good enough, and a little sanding and enough glue to fill the gap goes a long way toward making things right. As GRay said, printing in two parts provides a better surface finish. Pictured mounted on my extruders is the glued, two-part version. The one-piece version can also be seen in one of the photos, mostly as an indication of the print quality. A Blender data file for the axial version is included that contains both the "all-in-one" version and the "cutoff" and "toroid" pieces as separate objects. Only STL's are provided for the centrifugal version, as my Blender file contains far more than just the fan and shroud.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20 to 75%

Notes: Be sure you lay the bracket down on its side for printing.

You may have to do some sanding to clean up the finish in places, if you print the all-in-one-piece version.  The centrifugal version has some sharp edges in its design, you may want to sand those down.

For the "cutoff one, I imported GRay's two .stl files into Blender, combined them, cut off the part I didn't want, then re-drew the part I kept.
For the "one-piece" one, I combined the toroidal part of GRay's model with my redrawn version of the fan mount section, merged them into one object, extended the toroid along the Y axis to fit two extruders, moved it along the Y axis just slightly for better alignment, and then widened the output orifice by moving the outer walls further out and tapering the inner wall toward the nozzles.
I then copied the toroid part to a separate object, to be glued to the "cutoff" part if desired.
For the centrifugal version, I started by extracting a single-face cross-section of the original toroidal part, then used that as a guide while I drew a new shroud entirely from scratch, using Blender's "spin" tool to get a head start on creating the toroidal part.

description.text:
Here is all of the change, tumbler, and compound gears for the gingery lathe. You should be able to use them as is or use them for lost-pla casting for zamak, aluminum, or bronze.
If you plan on building a gingery lathe or any of the gingery machines, I would highly recommend buying the books. The physical copies are a great resource for information even after building the lathe and other machines. The physical copies also have a good bit more information in them than the online/ebook copies that Ive seen.
If needing to make custom gears, the modules is 1.058mm with a pressure angle of 24 degrees.

description.text: Diameter of Shakers will auto adjust length and width of the tray.  See Dimensions in the scad file.    Text can be either engraved or embossed.

Made a pair of headphones (really cushions) that have earbuds installed. It functions as a pillow, a pair of headphones and a tool for music lovers that listen while sleeping. My other name was musically comfortable. The design grants users a comfortable time while listening to music. Go CMS!
We worked together using our new colored PLA , warmed the machine up and plugged in the SD card that we downloaded from tinkercad!

#MakerEdChallenge Objectives: a good challenge is its own reward.
Audiences:7-8th grade, pre engineering classes
Preparation:Measure your ear perimeter and distance of ear to top of head. Use a comfy pillow material for the outside.
Steps: Pick good materials, hardware (audio) and plan out how the earphones fit into the pillow sock area without any place to agitate ear. Design for extra fluff pillow. Draw out and take measurements, design in tinkercad with ipod. Print out to see aesthetics and design test 1, go through process to modify and tighten it up!
Results:Students designed something meaningful to them which made their energy, focus and inspiration near and dear to their hearts. It brought our classroom closer together as we shared and enjoyed learning about everybodys interests. Thanks tinkercad/thingiverse! #MakerEdChallenge, #TechEdProject!

I was also printing at a low resolution so that has to be taken into account too.

title: Vertical Chessboard, aka The Cat Proof Chessboard

description.text:
The Vertical Chessboard, aka Cat Proof Chess Like most cats, my kitties look like adorable piles of fluff content on living a quiet life of napping and purring. In reality, however, they are little balls of evil and hate intent on destruction. Their favorite pastime is to look me in the eye while knocking down something that will produce a nice shatter or anything of value, but unattended chess pieces will do in a pinch. That’s why I made the Vertical Chessboard. It can easily be mounted on a wall, up and out of reach of their evil little paws. The chess pieces were modified from PerryT’s excellent chess set here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40605 The board pieces were printed at 200-micron layer height with 20% infill. No supports are needed.
The pieces were done at 100-micron layer height with 30% infill. They WILL need supports and lots of them. All together you will need to print: Black:
Top x3
Top Right x1
Bottom Left x1
Bottom x3
Left x3
Right x3
Center x19
King and Queen x1
Bishop, Knight, Rook x2
Pawn x8 White:
Top x3
Top Left x1
Bottom Right x1
Bottom x3
Left x3
Right x3
Center x19
King and Queen x1
Bishop, Knight, Rook x2
Pawn x8 And lots and lots of pins to put it all together. Notes:
The completed chess set in the images was printed at 80% scale.
The cat’s name is Two.
The top left and right pieces have keyhole slots to mount it on a wall but the completed print turned out to be so light I stuck mine up with poster tack instead.
This print will take several million years to complete and you could save time now by switching to a less time consuming hobby.

description.text:
I was tired of the 40mm fans breaking, so I designed a shroud for a 60mm fan I had sitting around. Some adjustments might need to be made to the spider mounting angle, as the shroud just barely hovers above the print layer. This was designed to mount on the right hand side, though mirroring it will easily let you mount it on the left. This will collide with the front towers, be careful. As the current iteration sits, due to the fact the air is directed pretty much on the nozzle, I had to retune my heater PID. This part has significantly increased my bridging capability though. UPDATE:
shroudV2 has a longer neck, focusing the air more on the part and less on the block. I have found that I can only do about 70% fan at 55mm/s with a .4mm nozzle printing this glow in the dark PETG though. Anything above that and the temperature drops, sometimes drastically. I am about to update it to be much more focused on the part.

Printer:

Geeetech G2S Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

80%

Notes: Simplify3D, 1mm support resolution
2 perimiter walls all around Orient the shroud so that the flange is angled in the air and the bottom of the shroud is on the bed.

author: Manusec

description.text:
Contributors:
  • Kevin Kelm [email protected]
  • Gary Rechnitz
    • Parametric Cookie Cutter is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License. This package contains code to turn DXF-based outlines into cookie cutters for 3D printers.

• 1.0.0 -- first release
  • 1.0.1 -- added filled imprints
  • 1.0.2 -- made inner flanges an option and defaulted it to false
  • 1.0.3 -- fiddled constants to be more realistic
  • 1.0.4 -- more documentation, new experimentation = new constants

Parametric Cookie Cutter (PCC) is intended to be used interactively by fiddling with global variables in cookie_cutter.scad via OpenSCAD. It may work with the command line, but I have no idea. PCC generates shapes with the following features:
  • A cutting edge that defines the shape of the cookie.
  • An imprint edge that defines the pattern stamped into the cookie.
  • A flange that sticks out from the top of the cutting edges and also optionally extends toward the center a small distance. This is for rigidity and to provide an easy surface to push on.
  • Optional strips going in both directions to support unconnected edges and internal peninsulas.
    • The quality of the results depends on a lot of factors (your skill as a baker aside). These include the complexity of the shape, its size, the quality of your print, whether you smooth your prints, and more. PCC allows you to build your cutter and imprinter in the same piece, but it's often wise to separate them so the imprint is done afterwards. The larger the surface area of the cutter/imprinter, the more the dough will stick to it. And of course if it sticks to it, then your cookie comes out looking funny (but tastes the same!). If you're up for the experiment, try it both ways. There are several categories of tunable variables in this package.

PCC allows you to name up to two DXF files containing the outlines of the cookie cutter patterns:
  • cutFilename: This is the path to the DXF file containing the shape of the cookie cutter itself. It's okay if curved edges have a low segment count; cookies are low resolution anyway.
  • imprintFilename: This optional DXF file is used to create a shallower "imprint" patter, allowing features to be baked into the center. In the included examples, the eyes and mouth of the smiley face and the trefoil of the radiation symbol are imprints. If you don't want an imprint, set this value to an empty string.
    • OpenSCAD can import simple DXF files, but it can handle only a small subset of the kinds of geometry people commonly use in DXF files. I have had no luck getting it to import anything with curves; they either come out as line segments or the file fails to load entirely. The easiest way to handle this is to have your software output your shape to an EPS file and then convert that file to DXF format. There are free online services like https://cloudconvert.com/eps-to-dxf to do this. The resulting DXF file will probably work with PCC. Note that when you see your shape in the 3D viewer, it will appear backwards; the design is flipped so the upper flange can be printed flat.

Now this is a hot mess. A lot of people work in AutoCAD, which may be using inches, feet, millimeters, or light years. In any case, DXF doesn't support units, so OpenSCAD has no way of knowing what the original intent was. As far as I know, most 3D printers think in millimeters, so that's my assumption in this package. To compensate, I added a scaling variable so nobody has to go back to the original editor and go through the hassle of several format conversions. This scales only the DXF file contents, not the features of the flanges and such:
  • scaleFactor: This is a multiplier used to mash around the geometry of the imported DXF files. This will almost certainly be an iterative process to see if you like the size of your object in Cura or whatever you're using.
    • Your object is expected to be near the origin. It must be a 2D path. Shapes don't need to be closed. The work area is defined as about 1 meter square, specifically for the creation of support strips (see below). 1 meter is a hell of a cookie, but I'm not judging if you want it to be larger. There's a constant in the file called workDiameter to declare this.

• Flanges. A flange is printed to strengthen the edges and provide a surface to press on to push the cutter into the dough. It's a little thicker than the edges. It sticks out, and it can also optionally stick into the shape a little as well. Sometimes playing with the flange sizes gives you the ability to skip the support strips, but it's a matter of balance and personal preference. If you make your imprints filled (see below), you may not need a flange on them unless you need the flanges to hold things in place. The flanges are controlled by the following variables:

    • cutFlangeRadius: This is the distance in mm that the flange sticks out from the cut edges. It also sticks into the shape by a fraction of the distance (default 7).
    • imprintFlangeRadius: This is the radius for imprint flanges (defaults to the value of cutFlangeRadius).
    • innerFlange: If this is set true, a flange about a third the size of the outer one will be generated aimed toward the inside of the shape. This is nice for structural reasons, but it can also interfere with trying to push the dough out after cutting the cookie (default false).

  • Support strips. Some shapes have internal floating features (like the smiley face example) or wobbly thin features (like the pi example). If you use imprints, you'll need to play close attention to this to make sure you have strips that support your internal unconnected edges. PCC will generate strips as part of the flange, controlled by the following variables:

    • numSupportStrips: The number of strips to generate in both directions. Set this to 0 if you don't want any. Strips are centered along the origin. Note that you can keep on incrementing this and see no result if you don't also decrease the spacing (described below). This is necessary because I fould no convenient means to have OpenSCAD calculate the bounding box of the shape.
    • supportStripWidth: The width in mm of each strip (default 4)
    • supportStripSpacing: The number of mm between strips, center-to-center (default 50).
  • Cutting/Imprinting. There are parameters to control how the edges are generated. The variables are:
    • fillImprints: Set this to true if you want your imprints filled instead of being cutting edges. If what you want is some mix of filled and not filled, you're going to have to do that yourself when you create the DXF by adding extra stuff inside the boundaries you want filled. For instance if you wanted to fill in a circle, you could add additional concentric circles inside it and let the imprint blade thickness take care of actually filling the space. If you set this to true, you may want to set the imprintFlangeRadius to zero unless you need it for support.
    • cutDepth: This is the depth in mm of the edge. This is a little bit of a misnomer because it's actually the depth of the entire object, including the flange. The cut depth limits the depth of the cookie that can be cut. If you want more height to accommodate thicker dough, change this (default 9).
    • imprintDepth: Like cutDepth, but for the imprint edges (default 7). Note that the result is affected by the depth of the cookie dough; If the dough is thinner than cutDepth, then the imprint depth will be less pronounced.
    • bladeThickness: This is the thickness in mm of the cutting and imprint blades (default 1.5). If you make it too thin, not only will it lose structural integrity but it may also result in the blade being holly and getting dough stuck in it.
    • Esoterica. The following variables are likely to be of no practical importance:
  • workDiameter: This is the area over which support strips are generated. If your cookies are greater than 1 meter then I guess increase this value. This was only necessary because I couldn't get the OpenSCAD tricks to work that would let me calculate the bounding box of the DXF contents so as to constrain the size of the support strips automatically.

I came into this completely naïve.  I'm an engineer, not a baker.  Cookies... dough... Pillsbury... easy, right?  My first attempt used peanut butter cookie dough from a tube and it made cookies that puff up like marshmallows, obliterating all details.  The smiley face looked like a bee sting victim.
Also my first attempts were way too deep; they were about 15mm deep on the cuts and 7mm deep on the imprints, stamped into dough about a half inch deep.  Also wrong.
Gary Rechnitz has included a recipe with some additional instructions.
Feel free to fork this in github and request pulls.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Since you're making a food surface, best use higher quality mode and smooth the results.

Also features a channel from the bottom thru to the front of the tool for threading wires to provide power for LED's. These can be strips that are stuck on to provide light to the front.

Added a new STL file - bbBracketNew - with the fat trimmed off. Use instead of bbBracket.stl to lessen print mass & time. Also a new build plate with the new part,

Main Bracket updated The mod for the main bracket left a gap of 0.05mm between the top & bottom that could cause weakness although this should not affect the printing, given that the difference is so small. description.text:
Put your favourite 3D print model into suspended animation inside a sealed glass chamber.
Just mount (glue) your model onto the base and screw it into the jar.
Use it as a key chain or as an ornament. I picked up these really cheap glass scintillation vials at Active Surplus (Queen St., Toronto). I wanted to use them as miniature display cases so this 3D model is a screw on cap for the vials.
The screw was designed specifically for this particular vial so I don't know what else it might fit. There are three versions of the cap with varying heights depending on how tall your model is. Each version comes with or without a hole for a keyring so there are actually 6 variants altogether in this thing.

title: ROBO 3D R1+ - no screw fan duct for Stock Hot End

description.text:
this is a remix (and combined with a couple other designs) .. for the ROBO 3D R1+ with the stock All Metal Hot End.
Everyone seemed to be going to the E3D v6 - but my stock all metal hot end is doing a great job. But it's shorter than the E3D v6 - hence the need for a modification.
Depending on how your printer handles bridges - print as oriented, or lay on side.
Mirror to change the side your fans will load. 
Use same file for front and back.

comments.text: It's working great on the back of my x carriage, but on the front the end stop sensor is in the way. Any suggestions or do I just need to do a little cutting to make room?
comments.author: gmayfield

comments.text: I think you may have a different x carriage than I have on my R1+. If you notice in the 1st pic, my carriage has a screw on it that hits the x-stop on the z-axis. I've heard that some have that just reversed with the x-stop on the carriage.
comments.author: gmayfield

comments.text: Snapped right on like a glove :-D Interested in seeing how much a difference it will make for bridging!
comments.author: TeutonicWolf

comments.text: So glad it's working for you .. I think you'll find a big difference for you on bridging - and over-all quality.
comments.author: TeutonicWolf

comments.text: Do you know if there is a version for 40x40x20mm fan?

comments.text: I don't know of a version for that .. but 20mm fans might be to much cooling - especially if you're using 2. The fans I'm using now - I only use 1 side anymore.

comments.text: to turn the fan speed down, you need to use your slicer program - I've used MatterControl, then SliCer, and now use Simplify3D ... in all of them there is the option to set the fan speed at a certain print layer. Try setting them to maybe 50% to see if that will help.

author: goldentuna1200

description.text:
In the challenge description, it said to design and 3-D print a project that will help kids learn in a classroom, so that's what I did. A gyroscope is a device consisting of a wheel or disk mounted so that it can spin rapidly about an axis that is itself free to alter in direction. Gyroscopes are commonly used for navigation systems, auto-pilot in planes, and stabilizers. In this gyroscope, there is a 3-D printed wheel with a diameter of five inches, and a thickness of three-quarters of an inch thick. In the center of the wheel, an axle is inserted and glued to the wheel. The motor, which is directly under the wheel, is pressed into the hole in the axle. In the box, the motor is fastened in by an extrusion. The motor fits snugly so that it will not shift and move. In the inner battery compartment, the battery box is stored (I used sticky Velcro to fasten the battery box to the side to prevent movement). On the side of the box, the on/off switch is snapped into the hole. The wires from the battery box and motor were soldered to the on/off switch, completing the circuit. Once turned on, the LED light on the switch will light up. Also, the wheel will begin spinning, eventually reaching approximately 5000 RPM. After everything is hooked up, the lid can be bolted onto the case. When the wheel gets to maximum speed, hold the box with the on/off switch facing upwards and turn the box clockwise or counterclockwise and feel the push for the wheel to level out. Remember, most of these parts are only plastic and are capable of getting cracked or broken, so use caution when bolting parts together and holding the project.
*For a list of the non-printed parts that I used, check the parts list at the bottom of the page.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

See misc. notes

Notes: Each of the following part's infill is listed here: Axle- 50% infill. Wheel- 40% infill. Box- 10% infill. Lid- 10% infill.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/h78xMvRAozo" ></iframe>

I used Autodesk Inventor 2016 student version for this project. It is a great piece of CAD software and I highly recommend using it. By using Inventor, you can design virtually anything. After I designed each part, I exported them as a .stl file and opened them in Cura, Ultimaker's 3-D printing software.

Parts List Motor: 5000 RPM 6V High Torque Cylinder Magnetic Electric Mini DC Motor
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00AUCGG6U?refRID=D9K31CTFQTPS9DACS15S&ref_=pd_ybh_a_23 On/off switch: HOTSYSTEM 10PC New 20A 12V Round Rocker Toggle Switch Blue LED
http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00ME1IQ7C/ref=twister_B0176AA4GG Battery pack: uxcell 2 Pcs 4 x AA 6V Battery Holder Case Box Wired ON/OFF Switch w Cover
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00H8PRPTE?refRID=BNGD1HE8BVZBGYZGR9XA&ref_=pd_ybh_a_5 Bolts: 0.8mm Pitch M5x40mm Stainless Steel Hex Socket Head Cap Screws 20 Pcs
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XP53K22?refRID=2P2A52XRXW82X9065NCC&ref_=pd_ybh_a_5

Objectives: By participating in the Physics Gyroscope project, students will learn how a gyroscope works, what type of force it uses, and why it resists from a lot of movement.
Audiences: High school students and college students are the targeted audience for this project because they are old enough to understand why it acts like it does.
Preparation: Before starting this project, students need to have batteries, a 5/38 hex screwdriver, and a creative mind.
Steps: First, download the attached ting files and print out the parts. Also, order the recommended parts that you cannot print. Once you have got all of your essential parts, solder one wire to each pole of the motor. Then feed the wires through the tunnel from the motor end so they come out the other side. Now, you can push the motor down into the extrusion. Next, feed those same two wires through the hole for the switch and solder them to the two outer prongs on the switch. Also, feed the wires from the battery box through the hole for the switch. Now, to complete circuit correctly, solder the positive wire from the battery box to the middle prong of the switch. The other wire (negative) gets soldered to the gold prong on the switch. There should be one wire on the outer, silver prong, on wire on the silver, middle prong, and two wires on the outer, golden prong. Then snap the switch into the hole. Now all you have to do is put the lid on, but before you do that, make sure the switch on the battery box is on. Lastly, set the lid on top and bolt it on.
Results: At the end of this project, students will have made a working gyroscope. They will be able to feel the force acting upon it, and they will have learned why that force is there. In order to get a grade, the student will have filled in a paper describing how it works, how well it works, and how long it took them to make it. The paper should be like a science lab report      over the gyroscope

print_settings.Printer:: My own derivative of the Prusa i3

title: Z-Endstop for Prusa i3 - Micro Adjustment for Opto - V2

description.text:
I needed a very finely adjustable Y-Axis end stop for an Opto-coupler. As I could not find
anything that met my needs I designed my own. There is a eye on the back of the body to cable tie the sensor cable I also added a body for the Idler side of the printer if you need to put the sensor on that side or if you are using two endstops in your firmware configuration. One full turn of the adjustment wheel moves the sensor 0.5mm.
The adjustment range is a full 12mm.
If that is not enough for you then move the whole thing up or down on the Z-Axis 8mm smooth rod until it is in the range were you need it to be. I designed the saddle mount for this Opto-coupler end stop sensor. I have included the original TurboCad (version 19 Pro) source file as well as .stp and .dxf file exports

2 - M3 50mm Allen Cap screws
1 - M3 25mm Countersunk Allen screw
1 - M3 20mm Dome head Allen screw 2 - M3 Nylock nuts
1 - M3 nut
2 - M3 Brass Inserts for plastic (Not absolutely necessary) 5 - M3 Washers
2 - Compression Springs - 17mm long by 5mm OD

Assemble the M3 25mm Countersunk Allen screw with one of the M3 Nylock nuts in the Saddle (See the attached images). You can clip the Opto sensor into the saddle after the M3 25mm Countersunk Allen screw and the M3 Nylock nut is tightened. 
Ream out the hole for the 8mm smooth rod with a 8mm drill bit as the hole will print a small bit undersize to ensure a tight fit on the 8mm smooth rod..
If you got the two M3 Brass inserts then drill the outer two 2.6mm holes on the top surface of the body out to 4mm. Melt the inserts into the new 4mm holes using the tip of a soldering iron. Cut the threaded part of the two 50mm Allen Cap screws to the same length as the inserts. Later you will want to screw them into the inserts without any of the thread sticking out the bottom of the inserts. For my inserts I had to cut the thread to 6mm length (see attached images). These inserts are available in 4mm, 5mm and 6mm lengths.
If you do not want to use inserts then tap  M3 thread into the two 2.6mm holes and cut the thread on the two 50mm Allen Cap screws to 4mm length.
Install the M3 20mm Dome head Allen screw and the other M3 Nylock nut in the 3mm clamping hole through the side of the body. Do not fully tighten it yet. You will do that after the assemble is installed on the 8mm smooth rod.
Fit the M3 nut into the adjustment wheel. Insert the adjustment wheel into the body so that the nut is in the top surface of the wheel. The nut will be trapped in the wheel by the body.
Insert the saddle assembly from the top of the body with the M3 25mm Countersunk Allen screw into the centre 3.5mm hole. Turn the wheel to screw the saddle assemble a few millimetres into it.
Assemble the washers and springs onto the previously prepared M3 50mm Allen Cap screws. Insert the screw and spring assemblies through the two holes in the black part of the sensor and screw them into the brass inserts (or M3 tapped plastic). Be careful to not over tighten these two screws. They must be just tight enough to not come loose by them self. If you used the brass inserts you can use thread lock on the screws to keep them from coming out accidently. If you screwed them into the plastic body then the tension of the plastic will keep them in. These two screws must not stick out of the bottom of the body as they will jam the adjustment wheel if they do. 
That’s it, you are done. Install it on your printer and enjoy.

Printer:

My own derivative of the Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: 0.4mm Nozzle. I printed with ABS. Bed at 120, Extruder at 240 degrees C using Simplify3D The body must be printed with support. The wheel and saddle does not need support.

description.text: My Technology teacher was awarded a grant to help improve the department's STEM classes.  Since one of the classes we have is a Robotics class, the teacher had the idea to build our own Quadcopter.  We were able to purchase the electronic parts we needed and we made a frame working with the parts we ordered.  He and I worked together to model all the different body parts in the 3D software SolidWorks.  The Quadcopter is fully built and we have attached cameras to it so we will be able to get an aerial view.

Printer Brand:

Stratasys

Printer:

uPrint SE Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.010in (0.254mm) or .013in (0.33mm) 30% Faster

Infill:

Solid

Notes: Print max size: 8" x 8" x 6".

Quadcopter Frame The Quadcopter frame was modeled to fit the parts we purchased. We also used a practical design and we kept in mind what the arms and the landing gear would look like. We also had to keep in mind that the maximum dimension for each of the parts could only be 8” as this is the size limitation for our 3D printer.

Objectives Designing a Quadcopter frame could be used as a final project for a Technology class. The goals of this project are to teach students about designing a model with limitations using the Design Process. Along with the overarching goal there are smaller goals such as: teaching basic Aerodynamics, using SolidWorks, learning about RC Quadcopters and learning about how to work in a group to finish a major project. Audiences This project is intended for High School students but students as young as 6th grade can work on this project with help from a Technology teacher who is used to teaching Middle School. There is no required skill level that the students must have. Since this would be a full year project, the students would be taught the SolidWorks program. Preparation The Student should have access to a computer with at least last year's version of SolidWorks (2014-2015) as there are new features in this version. To build the Quadcopter the teacher should be able to order a set of electronic parts that will be used. Access to a 3D printer is necessary. Steps The first part of the project would to be get ideas of how the Quadcopter should look and what you would want it to used for. After an idea has been formed, the electrical parts that are needed (such as: GPS, Transmitter, Receiver, Propellers, motors etc...) should be ordered. Once you have the parts you can start 3D modeling the frame around the dimensions of the parts. Once everything is printed, the pieces can be put together. Results At the end of this project the students should have designed and built a working Quadcopter. As part of this project the students should have also learned: the program SolidWorks, the basics of Aerodynamics, and an understanding of RC technology. In addition the students will have learned the design process: creating ideas, making many different models/prototypes, testing them, and if they do not work then create and find ways to fix the issue.

description.text: For some teachers, having a watershed/flooding diorama is a fantastic way to either teach budding engineers about the effects of a lot of water or get a janitorial nightmare. Either way,  this Flooding and Watershed Diorama can really be an easy benefit to teachers, students, and people who hate cleaning up spills in the classroom!

PLEASE READ I used the Google SketchUp CAD software to create the 1st and 2nd 3D models (which was both fun and a pain,) so it may not work for all types of 3D slicing software. I know for sure that the 1st model is quite iffy when it comes to 3D printing because of its complexity, and the 2nd model is probably the same (Sketchup is a bit glitchy.) Always test micro-versions of these models on your printer just to be safe.
IMPORTANT UPDATE:
The updated model is out and fully printable! I used 123D Design to do this one, so few or no problems.
If problems arise, please post them in the comments, and I will do my best to put out updated, upgraded versions. Thanks!

Objectives In this activity, students can learn:
-effects of a watershed/Continental Divide
-effects of erosion
-facts about dikes, dams, and canals
-and much more Audiences -any grade (K-12)
-any class interested in the engineering behind flood protection Preparations Basically, this diorama can be used for anything a teacher or student can think of for flooding, watersheds or erosion, but I can think of one suggestion that could be used in a classroom studying flood protection engineering. It requires:
-a small watering can of water (or more)
-a small package of clay (a cup of Play-Dough even)
-towels and a bucket for cleanup Steps
  • Either give each student (or group) a small diorama or have a larger, single diorama for the entire class
  • Explain the backstory: "Waterville is in big trouble! As if the irony was not enough, the forecast calls for heavy rain and a large chance for flash floods. With limited supplies and time, the townsfolk need to build a barrier to protect their homes from the flood. Can you save Waterville?"
  • Give each student or group a certain amount of clay or dirt to build a dike to keep Waterville from flooding using the smallest amount of time and clay possible.
  • Test with a "trial by water" to see if the student's separate or cumulative dikes can hold back the "raging flood." For an added or surprise effect, try using a garden hose or water pistol. (Yes, teachers can have fun with this too.)
  • Discuss the outcomes, and repeat if necessary.
    • Results The students should have been able to construct dikes that were able to hold back a sizable amount of water and keep Waterville dry, perhaps with some variety of strategies between students or groups. Teachers can grade students on how well their dikes did compared to the amount of clay they used.

This object is composed by 3 parts that together form a GPS tower and protective case for an RC plane Skywalker 1900/1800/1600 (2016) in the place that was supposed to be to placed perhaps a pan&tilt small fpv camera. I decided it was mor apropriated for a GPS antenna.
The case was designed to perfectly enclose a chinese Happymodel GPS antenna powered by M8n Ublox receiver that came with my Pixhawk clone.
The case is composed by the top and bottom parts and should be tightened with 3 M3 screws, preferably made with nylon to not disturb the antenna's magnetometer.
The bottom part is a perfect fit for the tower, and even though it is prepared to receive a 25mm M3 screw, when the pieces are fit, they'll hardly separate after.
The tower has hole that allows you to place the antenna's cables directly inside the plane minimising drag.
In case you have a Skywalker but have a different antenna you can still use the tower and the fitting part of the bottom case piece to make your own case. Don't mind about the long screws in the picture. At the time I joined the parts I didn't had a shorter M3 screw, so I used that just for those shots. I'll update the pictures when I have the right size M3 8mm nylon screws. For me printing this object with 100micron was enough for a great print! I hope you enjoy my first upload to thingiverse and have happy flying with your Skywalker!

Printer:

BQ Hephestos 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 micron

Infill:

10/20

Notes: For better results print all the parts with raft, the tower standing and both case parts with the inside pointing down so that the external parts get the best look.

This project aims to illustrate at the most basic level how additive manufacturing works using X, Y and Z Cartesian coordinates. The device simulates a 3D printer by having an X, Y and Z axis that have to be manipulated by hand whilst following predetermined coordinates and placing building blocks on the build plate.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa Mendel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50% Rectilinear

Notes: The part 'Extruder Slide' prints best with Support turned on at 2.5mm.
(I can only speak for the limited Bridging capabilities of my own Reprap) 8/14/2016
Please note that I have updated the build plate and building blocks to having square extrusions and cavities rather than the rounded ones as seen in the pictures. This was simply to aid the blocks from spinning once you started stacking them.

Bill of Materials 3D Print the following parts:
1 x Grid Base
1 x Extruder Slide (Includes a Bridge, Print with support if necessary)
1 x X Axis
1 x X Wedge
1 x Y Track Left
1 x Y Track Right
1 x Z Axis Tower Left
1 x Z Axis Tower Right
2 x Z Retaining Arm
80 x Block (You might need more if you want to build more complex shapes) You will need the following few items to build the device after the printing has completed.
  • 24.5cm x 28.5 cm MDF/Plywood Sheet - at least 20mm thickness
  • A Drill with a 3mm Wood/Steel bit
  • 8 Wood Screws - 5mm x 20mm
  • 2 Part Epoxy Glue
  • Access to a desktop printer to print the PDF template for drilling the holes.
  • Tape to hold the template in place on the wood
    • Assembly of the device First you need to obtain a suitable MDF/Plywood Sheet.
    Download the MDF Base Template PDF and print it. Make sure that you print using 100% scale and not the 'Fit to Page' setting.
    Line up the corner marked 'Bottom Left' on the template with the bottom left corner of your MDF sheet. Make sure that the edges are straight and use some tape to hold it in place. Drill the six holes that you can see on the template using a 3mm drill bit.
    If it all went to plan you should now have a board with six holes, and you can attach the 2 Y-Axis tracks and the build plate with your screws following the image below. Leave the screws on the Y-Axis tracks relatively loose. They should only hold the tracks down on the MDF base but the tracks should still be able to pivot around the screws slightly. We will tighten them later.
    (Please note that the holes at the top of the Y-Axis tracks should not be drilled until later) Six screws that should be fixed first Z- Axis Assembly This assembly requires some 2 part Epoxy glue. Take the two Z-Axis towers, and stand them upright on the inside of the Y-Axis tracks - numbers facing outwards. Insert the retaining arms into the cavities at the bottom of the towers so they grab onto the Y-Axis tracks firmly, but so that they can still slide up and down the track with ease. Once you are confident that everything fits into place you can remove the retaining arms, apply some Epoxy glue on the inside of the cavity and and reinsert the arms. Make sure that you don't spill any glue on moving parts that will stop them from moving later. Z-Axis Retaining Arm into Z-Axis Tower Both arms should fit snugly around the Y-Axis tracks but still be able to slide along the track with ease X-Axis Assembly The X-Axis consists of 3 separate parts.
    First step is to fit the Extruder Slide onto the X- Axis. Make sure that the numbers on the X-Axis are visible through the small cavity in the Extruder Slide and that it can move up and down along the Axis freely.
    Now you can place this assembly onto the Z-Axis towers. Slot it into the cavity marked '1' on both sides and then use the Wedge part to lock it into place. X Axis Assembly Fix the Y-Axis tracks Now that all the parts have been assembled you can align the two Y-Axis tracks and drill the last two holes.
    With the X-Axis locked into the 'Z1' position, slide the Z-Axis towers between the Y1 and Y9 positions. If the two Y-Axis tracks are not perfectly parallel to each other you will have some difficulty moving the Z-Axis towers. Keep adjusting the tracks until you feel comfortable that the Z-Axis towers can move freely. You can now tighten the two original screws on the Y-Axis tracks so they hold the part down. Once they are tight, slide the Z-Axis up to the Y1 position and make sure that there is still no binding. If you are happy that everything looks square, you can drill the last two holes and insert the screws. (Don't over tighten as you might cause the printed parts to crack) Drill and fix the last two screws if you are sure that the Z-Axis towers can move freely along the Y-Axis Finished! Your machine is now completely assembled and you can start creating shapes using the printed blocks and some X,Y,Z coordinates.

I designed the Plot XYZ using Solidworks.
Whilst designing I tried to bear in mind that all the parts fit onto the build plate of a Makerbot Replicator. Where I could, I ensured that the parts are uniform in thickness which should help avoid warping whilst printing. All the features are quite large to ensure that the parts will not break easily when operated by students in the classroom.

description.header: The Plot XYZ as a teaching tool
description.text:
Objectives The main objective of this device is to help students understand from a very young age how additive manufacturing works. It simulates the exact same movements of a 3D Printer following G-Code to create three dimensional objects.
Instructors can provide students with a set of X-Y-Z coordinates and ask them to create the model using this device and the printed building blocks. The process can also be reversed so that the students must write the X-Y-Z coordinates for an already existing model.
By the end of the exercise, students should have a very clear understanding of how objects are created in three dimensional space. Audience The Plot XYZ should be suitable for students from 8 and older. Younger students can start by creating very simple shapes using only the X and Y Axis. More advanced students can be asked to create advanced shapes utilizing all three Axes. Preparation If you can recognize the Letters X, Y & Z and count to 9, you should be able to operate this machine.
It is a very slow and methodical process and because it is all operated manually, a student can move at his/her own pace. Steps to get started Start by placing the Plot XYZ device and a large supply of the printed building blocks on a flat table.
Download and print Plot XYZ Workbook
Look inside to find Lesson 1.
Before you start, always move all the Axis' on the Plot XYZ to their home position, in this case X1, Y1, Z1.
Look at the first line of coordinates - X2, Y2, Z1.
Move each respective Axis to its numbered position. Once you are sure that each Axis is where it needs to be, take one of the blocks and drop it into place through the cavity on the Extruder Slide.
You'll notice that the second line of code and a few more lines after only have X and Y coordinates. This simply means that you leave the Z-Axis in place until you are instructed to move it to a new position.
Continue plotting all of the X and Y coordinates on the Z1 level. It is important to recognize that this type additive manufacturing machine works from the bottom up and that it always completes all of the X and Y coordinates on one level before moving up one step.
If you are patient and finish dropping the building blocks on all the correct positions, you should have an Upper Case 'T' that is two building blocks tall.
Pretty amazing how combining a bunch of numbers can create a three dimensional model! Now you can create your own models and write your own code. Completed Model of Letter T Spiral 3D Model Results This device should help any student understand the process of 3D printing and how cartesian coordinates are used by machines to create objects in three dimensional space.
If the student advances to a point where they are expected to create their own model and write code, they will also realize that when designing for 3D printing you have to account for certain physical limitations of the machine.
This will hopefully aid them when they design more complex objects using CAD at a later learning stage.
For pencils and more.

This is a holder for the Low Filament Alarm made by EndlessParts.com I got the alarm to warn me if I ran out of filament during a print and I wasn't there to watch it (still have to be in the area). I liked the piece of mind that I could be alerted if I was printing something and the spool was low. However - it didn't have a good mounting systems - so I used my remake of the ROBO filament guide (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1374081) and created a way to mount the alarm on it. I locks into the slot for the filament to feed - as seen in the photos. The alarm can be found here: http://goo.gl/Ds9ryI with YouTube videos/reviews.

description.text:
All credits to the original uploader. I only cut it in 3 to be able to print it large. On an UM2 you can make it almost 60cm high. If you scale one part, remember which scale value you printed it at and apply that value also to the other pieces! Otherwise you will be wasting many hours of printing. To help finding the max scale you can print:
  • The middle part is the highest
  • The bottom part is (of course) the widest
    • Check which scale values you can print each at maximum, and take the lowest value. Use that value for all 3 parts. For an UM2 you do not need to change the scale! If you use the 'maximize scale' tool of Cura, it will be made smaller. While scale 1 fits perfectly (already tested on my UM2). Disable the skirt in the advanced options then though. You can print the middle and top piece in one session, BUT, i guess it's quicker and it gives a better result to seperate those prints. Otherwise your printer has to travel back and forth every single layer, which doesn't add anything positive to the print.

description.text: This character was modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics (a stat card for this is included with the pictures). If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!

comments.text:
Trying the split version on a 166.6% scale as we speak.
First time trying out the company 3d printer, will post results when it's done.
comments.author: HeroNick

comments.text: Under what circumstances would you suggest using the split version rather than standing?
comments.author: songwind

comments.text: Honestly, we almost exclusively print split models at this scale. I've never been able to get supports to work for models this small/delicate on our machines, and unless you're good at perfectly calibrating your machine, standing models tend to get squirelly anyway. We've had the best results printing in halves and gluing together. For me, the seam is a smaller price to pay. But, if you can get good results standing, definitely do that. I've seen it done, so I know people can do it.

description.text: An Ellipsoidal planter I designed as a new home for some of my cacti.

Printer Brand:

Type A Machines

Printer:

2014 Series 1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes: I scaled the model to a height of 50 mm in my slicer and used my 2012-2013 plywood Series 1 to print the planter. Recommend printing upside down with rafts. I printed this without a raft, and the contact with the build surface was small enough that the part separated partly and lifted up, warping the pot near the lip. I also recommend using support material. I started the support at 60 deg. to prevent the overhang from collapsing in.
Nail Polish I printed the pot in PLA, a biodegradable polymer, so I used some nail polish to give the inside a protective coating, hence the Revlon 570 Vintage color on the interior.

description.text:
A classic Newton's Cradle that uses 6 pencils to reduce the amount of plastic required. Print 5 slings, 5 hangers and 4 supports. Use monofilament or string to hang the slings from the top rails. The slings are sized for a 1" ball bearing, adjust as needed for what size you use. I highly recommend printing a set of Hangers first to confirm they will fit your pencils, evidently pencil sizes vary greatly so you want to have a tight fit on the ones you have.
When assembling make sure the erasers are on the bottom of the assembly, this will keep it from moving when it is in action. You can use tape or glue to hold the top braces and hangers in place. I recommend glueing the ball bearings in the slings, the shock can pop them out if they are not tight.

Doesn't Matter

.2

10%

Notes: Adjust sizes of STL files to fit your materials!

comments.text: These were designed to be a very snug fit on the pencils I had on hand, if they are loose you lose energy very quickly. I apologize for not suggesting you print a sample first so you could test the fit, I'll adjust the instructions accordingly. Could be there is a difference in pencils used or settings between your printer and mine. Hope you were able to push through and get a working cradle, the one I created is still working great!

title: Micrometer metric base rotated for easy print (calibrated)

description.text:
This is a remix of Lt. Dan's micrometer only for easy of printing of the the base.
I tried printing his model just rotated so that i didn't have to use supports, and had a couple failed prints with the model getting unstuck as it was a small base for bed adhesion.
So just cut the model with a larger flat base but rotated so the overhangs are printable without support.
Works really well, on the first print.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:326566 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=326566

Using the following options: font_thickness = 3.3
text_font = orbitron.dxf
show_text = yes
text_size = 1
text_itself = Scorcho
This is my first original design from scratch. Opinions?

A simple and efficient travel sized container for holding quarters, it's a Piggy-Bank-on-the-Go! Easy to add or take away quarters, can be attached to bags or belt.
[Other coin sizes coming soon]

Parts and Functions: 3 -Main body tube: Holds quarters, with 4 "peep holes" to quickly see how many you have left (4/4, 3/4, 2/4, 1/4). Has a hole on the bottom big enough for a finger to push the coins up from the bottom if there isn't enough coins left to just take it from the top, but small enough that quarters won't fall out. [currently designing v.2. where the hole is not needed where there is a little slider that goes up and down] -Screw on cap
A simple lid with a slit on the top so you don't have to unscrew the cap every time the cashier gives you one or two quarters to put them in. It's small enough that it is very unlikely for any quarters to fall out when shaken. -Travel Ring
I put this in there so that I can attach the ring to the top of the inside of my book bag so that it is easy to reach, and easy to take out of the ring, just slide it in or out. You can also attach a small piece of cord or string to it and attach it to your belt.
I printed mine with 100 Microns with PLA with my Da Vinci Jr. 1.0 with 10% infill.
If there any suggestions or problems you come across while using it, I'd appreciate it and I'd include a fix for it in v.2.
[email protected] for any questions. I can print out one for you at https://www.3dhubs.com/user/120043/dashboard/hub if you don't own a 3D printer Happy Spending!
